['What are the many applications for angles?', 'As we discussed at the beginning of the section, there are many applications for angles, but in order to use them correctly, we must be able to measure them.']

['What is the most commonly used unit of angle measurement?', 'Probably the most familiar unit of angle measurement is the degree.']

['What else should we know?', 'Angles can occur in any position on the coordinate plane, but for the purpose of comparison, the convention is to illustrate them in the same position whenever possible.']

['What does that mean?', 'To draw a $$\\(360{^\\circ}\\operatorname{}\\)$$ angle, we calculate that $$\\(\\frac{360{^\\circ}}{360{^\\circ}} = 1.\\)$$']

['What is the arc?', 'An arc may be a portion of a full circle, a full circle, or more than a full circle, represented by more than one full rotation.']
['What is the length of the arc around an entire circle called?', 'The length of the arc around an entire circle is called the circumference of that circle.']
['What is the circumference of a circle?', 'The circumference of a circle is $$\\(C = 2\\pi r.\\)$$']

['What do you need to know to understand the circumference?', 'If we divide both sides of this equation by $$\\(r,\\)$$ we create the ratio of the circumference, which is always $$\\(2\\pi,\\)$$ to the radius, regardless of the length of the radius.']
['How does the radius affect this?', 'So the circumference of any circle is $$\\(2\\pi \\approx 6.28\\)$$ times the length of the radius.']

['What else is important about the radius?', 'That means that if we took a string as long as the radius and used it to measure consecutive lengths around the circumference, there would be room for six full string-lengths and a little more than a quarter of a seventh, as shown in Figure 10.']

['What is an angle formed at the center of a circle by two radii?', 'A central angle is an angle formed at the center of a circle by two radii.']

['What is the next topic that the class covers?', 'Note that when an angle is described without a specific unit, it refers to radian measure.']

['Is there a relation between arc length and radius?', 'Just as the full circumference of a circle always has a constant ratio to the radius, the arc length produced by any given angle also has a constant relation to the radius, regardless of the length of the radius.']
['What does the radius of the circle depend on?', 'This ratio, called the radian measure, is the same regardless of the radius of the circle—it depends only on the angle.']
['What is the significance of this measurement?', 'This property allows us to define a measure of any angle as the ratio of the arc length $$\\(s\\)$$ to the radius r. See Figure 12.']
